content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting
I'm not sure whom from the foundation group will be coming
@foundation-comms is this whom I should ping?
Hey! We're going to be along shortly - if you want to run through announcements first that would be good.
oh good idea
shoot, that reminds me, I meant to poke at that thing we talked about with @Matthew Jasper yesterday
didn't happen for me
I'm around btw
But I think more foundation-y folks will show up in a bit
trying to think if I have any announcements :)
well., there is going to be a foundation!
isn't that an announcement? :stuck_out_tongue:
before the foundation stuff
there was that bug that I just mentioned
and now that Niko's here
oh dear.
(because Niko was not able to attend mtg yesterday)
that bug
right
so
I'm trying to find the RFC
I'm speaking of rust#78893, for context
I remember we had an RFC that basically allowed us to include where clauses that can't be satisfied
https://rust-lang.github.io/rfcs/2056-allow-trivial-where-clause-constraints.html
it's a bit tricky to decide what kind of where clause to permit, in short
wait
that RFC just says "if its trivial, we should allow it", but also do the obvious thing
I'm kind of making the case for "this is not a bug"
i.e. if it cannot be satisfied, then no impl will ever be permtted
that's not what's happening in rust#78893, right?
I don't thnk so?
(FYI: I believe #79904 is related - though in many ways the "opposite" of #78893 - and caused broken crates in the last crater run)
oh, because the fn in question is never invoked?
okay okay
I guess it is indeed an instance of that then
the question kind of comes to "what does it mean for a where clause to be well-formed"
Okay. I'm willing to go along with "this is not a bug" at this point
we definitely want to permit where clauses that cannot be true
and this clearly fits in that category :)
I'm not sure about #79904, I haven't looked at that so closely, let me do that
I am a bit sad because I really wanted (but haven't found the time ... ) to sit down and kind of "model" our well-formedness and other rules in some simple model that we can review in lang team
:wave:
it's kind of been "bedeviling" chalk a bit
hello y'all
#79904 was injected by same PR
but probably not same category of "not a bug", right?
hmmm
hard to tell without an MCVE
they are certainly related
okay we should end discussiong of this no
now

FYI, the full set of regressions identified by crater that pertain to #73905 are:

  • failing to infer generic param when not explicitly stated #79905
  • trait bound no longer inferred for associated type #79904
  • unexpected unsized tail ICE #79902
  • Rustc nightly hangs and leaks memory #79714
  • No error reported when a generic parameter doesn’t meet the requirement of an associated type #78893
and move on to foundation Q&A
I have some theory for how to fix #79904 which may also cause #79543 to work -- will try to explore
maybe open with a big picture spiel about the foundation goals and maybe non-goals
in case some attendees haven't been reading those blog posts and/or FAQ
to start, there is a FAQ that you can read here which has a lot of details =)
I guess the big picture thing is that the purpose of the Rust foundation’s purpose is to enable Rust maintainers to joyfully do their best work.
In other words, the aim of the foundation is to support y'all and help our teams operate at their best :)
it also will be kind of "replacing" mozilla as the "legal host" for the rust project, which implies responsibility for things like trademark and legal policies
there will be a board with representatives drawn both from the project and from sponsor companies
you'll be learning more about those folks next month :)

I think a common question is "what kinds of things will the foundation do" -- it's perhaps a bit tricky to answer, because I think there are a lot of things it could do, but some of the ideas we've had are

  • training for leads and maintainers
  • running events like all hands or programs like Increasing Rust's Reach
  • helping to execute surveys and process results
  • paying for tools and services that a team needs
  • mediation support
one thing we do not expect it to do is to hire a bunch of developers, and some of our reasoning on that is explained here
I guess that's the end of my quick spiel :)
Another thing it does: provide a physical address for teams to use when e.g. code-signing (part of aforementioned "legal host" role)
One piece of that that I learned is that the foundation will essentially delegate the work like that to others; we won't have to worry about getting the foundation to approve each binary
others being who?
Awesome, our first question!
AFAICT the most plausible way forward is to just use SaaS with our own private key, but but that's still ourselves (the foundation) signing the binaries
(I think I know the answer to the question, but I'd prefer someone from the foundation outreach answer)
So I guess I just don't see where "foundation approves each binary" comes in.
Oh, the point of my comment there was that the foundation isn't approving each binary
tbh I don't really know a lot about this :)
but it's worth drilling in a bit in terms of what we mean when we say "the foundation", perhaps
i.e., the foundation will have a board of directors, and there is no way that the board of directors will 'approve' a binary or anything
Right. My understanding from what Ashley told the lang team on Wednesday is that the foundation will be able to delegate duties like this to the appropriate Rust teams.
but the foundation will also have some amount of paid staff, and one role in particular we expect is for it to have some folks dedicated to infra
while the legal liability will still lie with the foundation itself members
yes, the foundation is very much envisioned as a part of the project, almost a team of its own
and one that intends to trust rust teams with critical tasks (e.g., the implementation and design of the Rust compiler :)
Does that answer your Q, @nagisa ?
I do think legal liability can be delegated, it's probably something that has to be investigated on a case by case basis a bit

Yeah, I think so.

pnkfelix said:

while the legal liability will still lie with the foundation members

Is foundation not a legal entity itself (that can be liable as a whole, much like ltds are)? Why would members/employees of the foundation be suspect to liability?
it is a legal entity
Sorry, you're right
I should have just said "with the foundation"
and niko is right too: there may be cases where the legal liability is itself delegated
ashley specifically mentioned that in the case of an infrastructure person who is employed by the foundation
one area which I think will be interesting -- we've had this effort to clean up our licensing and provide better guidelines and so forth
I expect that the foundation will help to support that effort
the presence of a contract that the employee is agreeing to makes it easier to transfer liability when appropriate.
but obviously approving PRs in some sense takes on legal liability :)
so it's gonna be delegated
though this doesn't seem like the most exciting potential result of having a foundation to me
/me licensing = :zzz:
what are the things you are excited by here, @nikomatsakis ?
I'm pretty excited about having more support for organizational work
(BUT: lawsuits = :explosion: )
We've long talked about wanting to support our working group leads

I had another question: AFAIU we anticipate the foundation to hire a couple of key roles, one such role that came up, is infrastructure. Is there an idea at this point what other key roles may be (at least in broad categories)? Moderation and/or community teams seem like they are quite crucial to Rust's success, for instance.
how that is a lot of work for volunteers
I don't know how the foundation can help us with this, but I think it's the kind of thing the foundation is well positioned to do

@nagisa good question, I don't think we have "consensus answers". We've definitely tried to leave some things undetermined so that the future board of directors / executive director / foundation staff can own that question and find the best answers.

That said, some roles we've talked about are mediation and moderation, yes, along with communications, web presence, branding. I'm curious about things like "project management" and "product management".
The latter two are interesting, but what I've found is that there are people who can really help work with you to "tease out" the important bits of a roadmap
i.e., not make the roadmap for you, but help you make it
I could imagine the foundation hiring people to play that role at some point, though I think that might also be a role that the various Rust teams that are coming into existence could fill, or both
@nagisa I pick up on community, I feel like can answer that well.
/me should stop talking so much

nikomatsakis said:

The latter two are interesting, but what I've found is that there are people who can really help work with you to "tease out" the important bits of a roadmap

You mean in terms of e.g. asking the right questions to force you to narrow scope accordingly?
@Florian Gilcher yeah say more

So, there's an interesting balance there: I don't think the foundation can take over a lot of the stuff that the community team does competently - it has a very fragmented working style, distributed around the world, in very small time slices.
_But_, and I think that is something that we see at a lot of places: I see a ton of things where the foundation can _augment_ what community team members do.
I'm going to keep it at this level, as community team has a session soon (hopefully January) where we will talk about this.
Cool, a lot of interesting insights here. Thank you.

Florian Gilcher said:

_But_, and I think that is something that we see at a lot of places: I see a ton of things where the foundation can _augment_ what community team members do.

I see this as a key point
not just for community team
But there's definitely the intention to make sure we have something coherent there and not two independent groups communicating :)
I'd like to hear more about how the sponsors interpret the position of the foundation and of their role in it.
e.g. do they expect to have significant influence on project direction via the foundation?
So, @ag_dubs has done the vast majority of direct communication with sponsors
so I'm relating things a bit second hand as I think she's still in another meeting
one thing she has said numerous times though is that a lot of folks are worried about a perception of "buying" or "taking over" the rust community and actively don't want that
( We could alternatively take another question while we wait for ag_dubs?)
(don't want the reality...and probably not the perception either:)
and by "folks" there, you include the sponsors themselves, right?
er, yes, I meant specifically the sponsors
I know its an active concern at my employer.
it's a founding principle that the teams should retain their traditional decision making roles for the most part, which implies that sponsorship doesn't let you make technical decisions
(though I personally am curious -- and have been for some time! -- to see us have clearer, more welcoming pathways for companies to approach with ideas they'd like to pursue)
(or other groups)
(kind of a red herring though as I don't necessarily see that as related to the foundation)
not sure @Florian Gilcher or others if you have thoughts or comments on this topic...
(or other questions?)
(i think I need a bit to draft :), so maybe another question in between?)
One item from the FAQ that I want to specifically point out is "Will the foundation hire every Rust contributor?"
from the dialogue above, you can infer the answer starts with the word "No,"
Is there a rough timeline of when we might expect to see the Foundation launched? Is this likely in early/mid/late 2021 or is there just too many factors to guess?
but its also worth mentioning that the foundation is structured to incentivize sponsor companies to hire team members.

Wesley Wiser said:

Is there a rough timeline of when we might expect to see the Foundation launched? Is this likely in early/mid/late 2021 or is there just too many factors to guess?

Expect updates in early January :)

I'll just quote our blogpost:

We expect to launch the Foundation officially early next year!

pnkfelix said:

but its also worth mentioning that the foundation is structured to incentivize sponsor companies to hire team members.

to elaborate a bit on this, we give discounts to sponsors who hire Rust team members, but those members must have 100% time to work on Rust (not to work in Rust)

This kind of fits with the Foundation goal of supporting maintainers -- we want to incentivize companies to get involved with Rust financially. I personally think it'd be much better if we can get a bunch of companies hiring people, as it also means that those people will have a wider variety of background experiences and influences. (In short, I want companies to get invested in Rust by participating actively in the teams more than I want them to just give $$)
(though I'll take the $$)

pnkfelix said:

I'd like to hear more about how the sponsors interpret the position of the foundation and of their role in it.

So, my salomonic answer there is that _our_ interpretation of the foundation is what sponsor buy into. For that reason, making sure the foundation and its staff is aligned and in a good relationship with the Rust project is crucial. It needs to understand its needs directly.

We have communicated the role of the foundation as a project support structure and oriented towards maintainers.
we're approaching the end of the hour
feel free to ping with questions if you have any
where is best place to send those, actually?
ashley I think mentioned that the repo is still being maintained
well I meant just privmsg or something
(i.e. issues filed there are responded to)
but you could file issues on the faq repo, yes
So either deluge niko with privmsgs
or file an issue, at ... which repo ...
at some point we'll prob make it readonly, but not yet (it's open to team members I think)
https://github.com/rust-lang/foundation-faq-2020
I can't speak for the latency in which an issue filed there will be answered though :)
seems like all the ones from a week ago have been handled

nikomatsakis said:

it's open to team members I think

Can confirm it is open; at least I'm able to create an issue if I wanted to.

pnkfelix said:

but its also worth mentioning that the foundation is structured to incentivize sponsor companies to hire team members.

Was there somewhere where it is explained what incentives there are for sponsors to be sponsors?
so, that's not bad

varkor said:

pnkfelix said:

but its also worth mentioning that the foundation is structured to incentivize sponsor companies to hire team members.

Was there somewhere where it is explained what incentives there are for sponsors to be sponsors?

great Q
I didn't see any mention in the FAQ.
by this do you mean
what discounts on pricing etc are available
(Sorry for arriving so late.)
or do you mean "why would anyone sponsor this anyway"
I think they mean "why would you be a sponsor"
or do you mean "what do you get from being a sponsor"

nikomatsakis said:

or do you mean "what do you get from being a sponsor"

Right, this.
or "why would a company be a sponsor"
(to be honest answers to all of these questions sound interesting to me)
Heh ok :)
so "why wuld you sponsor this anyway" -- because you believe the rust org is worth maintaining and is important to your business

from the why a 501c6 answer:

The practitioners here are the users and maintainers of Rust, and the craft is using Rust. The interesting part is deciding what “improving business conditions” means. In our case, we are very explicitly defining our common interest as the health, vibrancy, and sustainability of the Rust open source organization as being the most direct way to improve the craft of using Rust. We think we are in a moment where folks are questioning the economic and organizational models around open source and are looking for a change and we’ve had enthusiastic reception from potential sponsors!
(emphasis mine)

nikomatsakis said:

or do you mean "what do you get from being a sponsor"

in terms of this...
There are various tiers. The top tier gets you a board seat, the other tiers let you vote (along with other people at that tier) for a shared board seat. So one thing you get is a voice on the board.
You also get publicity
(oh that "why a 501c6" answer is super interesting, I recommend people go read it in full)
I'm not sure what else :)
(namely the distinction between what most other Open Source projects put as their interest, vs what rust is doing)
I think that's about it, maybe we'll add other things, like mentions in a newsletter, or prominent placement on a job board (these are things i've seen at other foundations)

nikomatsakis said:

I'm not sure what else :smile:

There was "what kinds of discounts do sponsors get for hiring a member" but I think its fine to call the meeting as we're overtime too.
in terms of 'what discounts are available' -- I'm not sure how much we've said publicly -- but I'll say the only exciting one is for employing someone to work on Rust. :P
The role of the board concretely, other than appointing other board members, isn't so clear to me from the FAQ.
We've hit the hour. Obviously more answers may come in, and I hope they do
Perhaps I should ask these questions on https://github.com/rust-lang/foundation-faq-2020 instead of in the last minute during the meeting :)
but just to check: Will the questions and answers here be incorporated into the FAQ if they haven't already come from the FAQ in the first place?

varkor said:

Perhaps I should ask these questions on https://github.com/rust-lang/foundation-faq-2020 instead of in the last minute during the meeting :)

(I do think an issue there is probably the best way to ensure the question is answered in a way that the community at large will see it)

pnkfelix said:

but just to check: Will the questions and answers here be incorporated into the FAQ if they haven't already come from the FAQ in the first place?

I'd say file an issue if you think there's something in there
okay, thanks

varkor said:

Perhaps I should ask these questions on https://github.com/rust-lang/foundation-faq-2020 instead of in the last minute during the meeting :)

sounds good
thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! And thank you to the foundation working group. Y'all both are awesome.
